definitions.definition: to continue to have something and not give it back or throw it away

examples.text: He kept all her letters.
She handed the waiter a hundred dollar bill and told him to **keep the change**.
Always keep a backup of the file.

definitions.definition: to put or store something in a particular place

examples.text: Keep your passport in a safe place.
Where do you keep the sugar?
The documents are all kept under lock and key.

definitions.sensetop: keep something for somebodykeep somebody something

examples.text: Please keep a seat for me.
The man in the shop said he'd keep it for me until Friday.
Please keep me a seat.

definitions.definition: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
definitions.sensetop: keep + adj.keep + adv./prep.keep somebody/something + adj.keep somebody/something + adv./prep.keep somethingkeep somebody/something doing something

examples.text: We huddled together to **keep warm**.
I could not keep silent any longer.
The notice said ‘Keep off *(= Do not walk on)* the grass’.
Keep left along the wall.
The doctors worked miracles to **keep** him **alive**.
Winning the contract means they can now **keep** the factory **open**.
She kept the children amused for hours.
Keep your PIN safe.
He kept his coat on.
Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?
She had trouble **keeping her balance**.
I'm very sorry to **keep you waiting**.
I'm amazed that she keeps so cheerful.
Keep close to me.
She needed to keep busy.
Sit down and keep calm!
Try to keep active in the cold weather.
We managed to keep dry by standing in a doorway.

definitions.definition: to continue doing something; to do something repeatedly
definitions.sensetop: keep doing somethingkeep on doing something

examples.text: Keep smiling!
Why does everyone **keep saying** that?
Things just **keep getting** worse.
Don't keep on interrupting me!

definitions.definition: to know something and not tell it to anyone
definitions.sensetop: keep a secretkeep something secret (from somebody)

examples.text: Can you keep a secret?
She kept her past secret from us all.

definitions.definition: to do what you have promised to do; to go where you have agreed to go

examples.text: She **kept her promise** to visit them.
Mary **kept her word** and Henry was never informed.
He failed to **keep his appointment** at the clinic.

definitions.definition: to write down something as a record

examples.text: She **kept a diary** for over twenty years.
We **keep a record** of all complaints that we receive.
Keep a note of where each item can be found.
I kept a weekly account of my workload and activities.
Separate accounts must be kept for each different business activity.
Village clerks were unable to keep a proper record of deaths because they were so frequent.

definitions.definition: to own and care for animals

examples.text: to keep bees/goats/hens
My grandmother kept chickens in her back yard.
Residents are not allowed to keep pets.

definitions.definition: to own and manage a shop or restaurant

examples.text: Her father kept a grocer's shop.

definitions.definition: to provide what is necessary for somebody to live; to support somebody by paying for food, etc.

examples.text: He scarcely earns enough to keep himself and his family.
At the time many working men did not earn enough to keep a wife and children.
He kept himself by giving private lessons.
You're an hour late—what kept you?
I won't keep you long. I've just got a couple of quick questions.

definitions.definition: used to ask or talk about somebody’s health

examples.text: **How is** your mother **keeping**?
We're all keeping well.
Finish off the pie—it won't keep.
Milk and cream should keep quite well in a fridge.
‘I'd love to hear about it, but I'm late already.’ ‘That's OK—**it'll keep** *(= I can tell you about it later)*.’
May the Lord bless you and keep you *(= used in prayers in the Christian Church)*.
His only thought was to keep the boy from harm.

definitions.definition: to guard or protect the goal or wicket
to make an effort to live normally when you are in a difficult situation or when you have experienced great pain and difficulty

examples.text: You just have to keep yourself busy and keep going.

definitions.definition: used to encourage somebody to continue doing something

examples.text: Keep going, Sarah—you're nearly there.

definitions.definition: to be enough for somebody until they get what they are waiting for

examples.text: Have an apple to keep you going till dinner time.

wordOrigin: late Old English cēpan ‘seize, take in’, also ‘care for, attend to’, of unknown origin.
